20110105040520.000|20110105040522.000|TR0|the provision of health care.  In my state

20110105040524.000|20110105040526.000|TR0|in an entire year to provide someone with 
20110105040526.000|20110105040528.000|TR0|complete health care from what it does to

20110105040815.000|20110105040817.000|TR0|the point I'm coming to, as you just 
20110105040817.000|20110105040819.000|TR0|acknowledged a moment or so, the provider 
20110105040819.000|20110105040822.000|TR0|ends up eating the bill and the taxpayers 
20110105040822.000|20110105040824.000|TR0|cover it.  We call it charity care. 
20110105040824.000|20110105040826.000|TR0|Taxpayers pay back the hospitals and those 
20110105040826.000|20110105040828.000|TR0|who provided the care to cover the cost of

20110105040834.000|20110105040836.000|TR0|Romney, a very conservative Republican on 
20110105040836.000|20110105040838.000|TR0|down, said the only way to cover that cost

20110105040900.000|20110105040902.000|TR0|state level.  The concept itself can be 
20110105040902.000|20110105040904.000|TR0|appealing but again it matters.  It's not 
20110105040904.000|20110105040906.000|TR0|just a question of what is the role of 
20110105040906.000|20110105040908.000|TR0|government.  It's also a question of which 
20110105040908.000|20110105040910.000|TR0|government, and a question we've got to 
20110105040910.000|20110105040912.000|TR0|start asking ourselves in this country 
20110105040912.000|20110105040914.000|TR0|again, and especially at a time when we've 
20110105040914.000|20110105040917.000|TR0|got a debt that's approaching $15 
20110105040917.000|20110105040919.000|TR0|trillion, is which government?
20110105040919.000|20110105040921.000|TR0|
20110105040921.000|20110105040923.000|TR0|It's not always a federal solution.
20110105040923.000|20110105040925.000|TR0|
20110105040925.000|20110105040927.000|TR0|SPITZER:  I'm just trying to figure out as 
20110105040927.000|20110105040929.000|TR0|a matter of policy whether the individual 
20110105040929.000|20110105040931.000|TR0|mandate, which is the obligation that 
20110105040931.000|20110105040933.000|TR0|everybody buy into the system and pay 
20110105040933.000|20110105040936.000|TR0|something into it, since we all get health 
20110105040936.000|20110105040938.000|TR0|care, whether is a policy matter that 
20110105040938.000|20110105040940.000|TR0|makes sense to you.  Because I think then 
20110105040940.000|20110105040942.000|TR0|the subsidiary question is whether the 
20110105040942.000|20110105040944.000|TR0|states do it or the federal government.  
20110105040944.000|20110105040946.000|TR0|But you seem almost to be saying, yes, you 
20110105040946.000|20110105040948.000|TR0|understand the logic for that.
20110105040948.000|20110105040950.000|TR0|
20110105040950.000|20110105040952.000|TR0|LEE:  Yes, I understand the logic of it 
20110105040952.000|20110105040955.000|TR0|and I understand why some states might 
20110105040955.000|20110105040957.000|TR0|want to do it.  I'm saying, it needs to be 
20110105040957.000|20110105040959.000|TR0|decided on a state-by-state basis.  As a 
20110105040959.000|20110105041001.000|TR0|federal legislator, I'm agnostic as to the 
20110105041001.000|20110105041003.000|TR0|underlying policy question of whether it's 
20110105041003.000|20110105041005.000|TR0|a good idea because it's a state question. 
20110105041005.000|20110105041007.000|TR0| Not a federal one.
20110105041007.000|20110105041009.000|TR0|

20110105041130.000|20110105041132.000|TR0|Income" and what it does is it compares 
20110105041132.000|20110105041134.000|TR0|groups of individuals by the amount of 
20110105041134.000|20110105041136.000|TR0|income they receive versus the taxes they 
20110105041136.000|20110105041138.000|TR0|pay.  And from the left, what it says is

20110105041140.000|20110105041143.000|TR0|percent of -- have the lowest 20 percent 
20110105041143.000|20110105041145.000|TR0|of income which is in aggregate about 4 
20110105041145.000|20110105041147.000|TR0|percent of all income, pay about 3 percent 
20110105041147.000|20110105041149.000|TR0|of all taxes.
20110105041149.000|20110105041151.000|TR0|
20110105041151.000|20110105041153.000|TR0|Then next 20 percent has about 6 percent 
20110105041153.000|20110105041155.000|TR0|of all income and pays about 5 percent of 
20110105041155.000|20110105041157.000|TR0|all taxes.  And so, really, what you're

20110105042000.000|20110105042002.000|TR0|SPITZER:  So if I understand you properly, 
20110105042002.000|20110105042004.000|TR0|Mr. Khan, what you are suggesting is that

20110105044018.000|20110105044020.000|TR0|would care about if it was presented in a 
20110105044020.000|20110105044022.000|TR0|way, but the Republicans don't have a 
20110105044022.000|20110105044025.000|TR0|mandate for what they see.
20110105044025.000|20110105044027.000|TR0|
20110105044027.000|20110105044029.000|TR0|PARKER:  The people do not want an 
20110105044029.000|20110105044031.000|TR0|expanding, ever-expanding government that 
20110105044031.000|20110105044033.000|TR0|spends incessantly but they also don't 
20110105044033.000|20110105044035.000|TR0|want to give up anything that comes to 
20110105044035.000|20110105044037.000|TR0|them directly.
20110105044037.000|20110105044039.000|TR0|
20110105044039.000|20110105044041.000|TR0|CAIN:  Absolutely true.
20110105044041.000|20110105044044.000|TR0|
20110105044044.000|20110105044046.000|TR0|PARKER:  Yes.  So how do you reconcile 
20110105044046.000|20110105044048.000|TR0|those two opposing needs?
20110105044048.000|20110105044050.000|TR0|
20110105044050.000|20110105044052.000|TR0|VANDEN HEUVEL:  But you know, there's a 
20110105044052.000|20110105044054.000|TR0|growth budget that needs to -- you know,

20110105044056.000|20110105044058.000|TR0|operating and an investment budget.  And I 
20110105044058.000|20110105044101.000|TR0|think we are at a point if we want to have

20110105044103.000|20110105044105.000|TR0|the system.  That's not left/right.

20110105044607.000|20110105044609.000|TR0|    STEIN:  Well, no.  I mean, my father, 
20110105044609.000|20110105044611.000|TR0|a very smart guy, used to say if a thing

20110105044732.000|20110105044734.000|TR0|STEIN:  We're having a recovery.  There's 
20110105044734.000|20110105044736.000|TR0|almost no doubt about that.  The market is

20110105044742.000|20110105044745.000|TR0|just mentioned, corporate profits are 
20110105044745.000|20110105044747.000|TR0|extremely strong and getting stronger.  
20110105044747.000|20110105044749.000|TR0|So, the market -- the market doesn't 
20110105044749.000|20110105044751.000|TR0|really care that much. The market is a 
20110105044751.000|20110105044753.000|TR0|heartless beast.  It doesn't care that 
20110105044753.000|20110105044755.000|TR0|much about an unemployed family in Flint, 
20110105044755.000|20110105044757.000|TR0|Michigan.  They don't care about those 
20110105044757.000|20110105044759.000|TR0|people.  The market cares about stocks and 
20110105044759.000|20110105044801.000|TR0|the earnings on stocks and those are doing 
20110105044801.000|20110105044804.000|TR0|very well.  It would be nice if the market

20110105044850.000|20110105044852.000|TR0|
20110105044852.000|20110105044854.000|TR0|PARKER:  Professor Stein, on the -- even 
20110105044854.000|20110105044856.000|TR0|though, you know, debt or no debt, isn't 
20110105044856.000|20110105044859.000|TR0|it a good thing?  Isn't it overall a good 
20110105044859.000|20110105044901.000|TR0|thing when the market is doing well?  
20110105044901.000|20110105044903.000|TR0|Doesn't that work well for us ultimately?
20110105044903.000|20110105044905.000|TR0|
20110105044905.000|20110105044907.000|TR0|STEIN:  It's a great -- it's a great thing 
20110105044907.000|20110105044909.000|TR0|unless it gets so high then it crashes.  
20110105044909.000|20110105044911.000|TR0|But sure, we want people to feel wealthy.  
20110105044911.000|20110105044913.000|TR0|We want them to go out and spend.  We want 
20110105044913.000|20110105044916.000|TR0|them to feel optimistic.  There is a thing 
20110105044916.000|20110105044918.000|TR0|called the wealth effect in which some 
20110105044918.000|20110105044920.000|TR0|small amount of the markets increase as 
20110105044920.000|20110105044922.000|TR0|translated into an increase in consumption 
20110105044922.000|20110105044924.000|TR0|and people feel just generally happier.  
20110105044924.000|20110105044926.000|TR0|And I think that's happening. There is a 
20110105044926.000|20110105044928.000|TR0|lot of psychological data to be sure, most 
20110105044928.000|20110105044930.000|TR0|of it probably made up, that says when the 
20110105044930.000|20110105044932.000|TR0|market is up, people spend more money and 
20110105044932.000|20110105044935.000|TR0|the whole economy improves.  And I think 
20110105044935.000|20110105044937.000|TR0|that's happening right now. I think people 
20110105044937.000|20110105044939.000|TR0|are in a better mood because the market is 
20110105044939.000|20110105044941.000|TR0|up.  I mean, I know I am.  So we'll assume 
20110105044941.000|20110105044943.000|TR0|that everyone is.
20110105044943.000|20110105044945.000|TR0|
20110105044945.000|20110105044947.000|TR0|PARKER:  I'm in a better mood just talking
